title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) — In the long and storied rivalry between the Boston Celtics and Philadelphia 76ers, there have been countless battles. But on this night in 1998, the game was reduced to a simple, breathtaking truth: Antoine Walker could not be stopped.

Walker, the Celtics' dynamic forward, authored a performance for the ages, pouring in a career-high and utterly dominant 42 points to single-handedly carve up the 76ers in a 107-101 Celtics victory.

From the opening tip, it was clear Walker was operating on a different plane. He was a whirlwind of activity, scoring from every conceivable spot on the floor. Whether he was draining long jumpers, bullying his way to the basket, or capitalizing on his teammates' playmaking, the Philadelphia defense had no answer. His 42-point eruption wasn't just high volume; it was breathtaking efficiency and sheer will, a historic scoring feat that left the Philly faithful in a state of stunned silence.

While Walker’s spectacular night rightly commands the headlines, he was not without a formidable co-star. Kenny Anderson orchestrated the offense with a brilliant 18-point, 13-assist double-double, serving as the perfect facilitator for Walker’s scoring onslaught. On the other side, the 76ers fought valiantly, led by Allen Iverson’s 27 points and a massive 22-rebound effort from Derrick Coleman. But their combined heroics were no match for the one-man wrecking crew in green and white.

Ultimately, this was not merely a win for the Celtics; it was the night Antoine Walker arrived as a bona fide superstar, delivering a legendary performance that will forever be etched into the lore of the Celtics-76ers rivalry. He didn't just beat Philadelphia; he overwhelmed them.
